['Opening discussion to ""The Convent-garden tragedy""', '""It hath been customary with authors of extraordinary merit to prefix to their works certain commendatory epistles in verse and prose, written by a friend, or left with the printer by an unknown hand; which are of notable use to an injudicious reader, and often lead him to the discovery of beauties which might otherwise have escaped his eye. They stand like champions at the head of volume, and bid defiance to an army of critics."']
['Located on p.300, 303, 305, 307', 'Marked by smaller type.']

['Prologue to ""The Convent-garden tragedy""', 'Prologue written in verse.', '""In Athens first (as dictionaries write)--- The tragic muse was midwif\\\'d into the light;--- Rome knew her next, and next she took a dance, Some say to England, others say to France."']

['Epilogue to ""The Convent-garden tragedy""', 'Epilogue written in verse.', '""In various lights this night you\\\'ve seen me drest,--- A virtuous lady, and a miss confest;--- Pray tell me, sirs, in which you like me best?--- Neither averse to love\\\'s soft joys you find;--- \\\'Tis hard to say which is the best inclin\\\'d."']
b: ['Epilogue. Spoken by Miss Raftor, who acted the parts of Isabel in The old debauchees, and of Kissinda in this Tragedy.']

x: ['Prologue written in verse', 'Prologue to ""The debauchees""', '""I wish, with all my heart, the stage and town--- Would both agree to cry all prologues down;--- That we, no more oblig\\\'d to say or sing,--- Might drop this useless necessary thing:--- No more with awkward strut, befor the curtain,--- Chaunt out some rhimes-- there\\\'s neither good nor hurt in."']

['Dedication to ""The debauchees""', '""My lord, As there is scarce any vanity more general than that of desiring to be thought well received by the great, pardon me, if I take the first opportunity of boating the countenance I have met with from one who is an honour to the high rank in which is born."']
b: ['To his grace Charles duke of Richmond and Lennox.']

x: ['Prologue to ""The Miser""', 'Prologue written in verse.', '""Too long the slighted comic mule has mourn\\\'d,--- Her face quite alter\\\'d, and her art o\\\'erturn\\\'d;--- That force of nature now no more she sees,--- With which so well her Johnson knew to please."']
b: ['Prologue. Written by a friend. Spoken by Mr. Bridgewater.']

x: ['Epilogue written in verse.', 'Epilogue to ""The miser""', '""Our author\\\'s sure bewitch\\\'d! The senseless rogue--- Insists no good play wants an epilogue."']
b: ['Epilogue. Written by Colley Cibber, esq. Spoken by Miss Raftor.']

x: ['Dedication to ""The ingenius chambermaid""', '""Madam, if address of this nature (notwithstanding the base purpose to which they have been perverted) were originally intended to express the gratitude of the author for some favour received, or to celebrate the merit of some particular friend; I think you have a very just title to this."']

['Written in verse.', 'Paratext to ""The intriguing chambermaid""', '""While wit, like persecution, reigns, and all--- Must in the furious inquisition fall,--- Untry\\\'d, unheard: while guiltless crouds [sic] expire,--- Martyrs to spleen! in each poetick fire;--- Nor characters, nor worth, nor sex, nor age,--- Nor sacred majesty escapes her rage;--- Against example who shall dare commend?--- Avow good-nature, or confess the friend!"']
b: ["To Mr. Fielding, occasioned by the revival of the author\\'s farce. Sent to the author by an unknown hand."]

x: ['Prologue written in verse.', 'Prologue to ""The intriguing chambermaid""', '""As when some ancient hospitable seat,--- Where plenty oft has giv\\\'n the jovial treat,--- Where in full bowl each welcome guest has drown\\\'d--- All sorrowing thoughts, while mirth and joy went round,--- Is by some wanton worthless heir destroy\\\'d,--- Is once full rooms grown a deserted void;--- With sighs, each neighbour views this mournful place;--- With sighs, each recollects what once it was."']
b: ["Prologue. Upon the revival of the Author\\'s farce. Spoken by Mrs. Clive."]

x: ['Epilogue is written in verse.', 'Epilogue to ""The intriguing chambermaid""', '""A poet should, unless his fate be guest,--- Write for each play two epilogues at least."']

['Dedication to ""Don Quixote in England""', '""My lord, However unworthy these scenes may be of your lordship\\\'s protection, the design with which some of them were written, cannot fail of recommending them to one who hath so gloriously distinguished himself in the cause of liberty, to which the corruption I have here endeavoured to expose may one day be a very fatal enemy."']
b: ['To the right and honourable Phillip Earl of Chesterfield, knight of the most noble order of the garter.']

x: ['Preface to ""Don Quixote in England""', '""This comedy was begun at Leyden in the year 1728; and after it had been sketched out into a few loose scenes, was thrown by, and for a long while no more thought of."']
['Introduction to ""Don Quixote in England""', '""No prologue, sir! The audience will never bear it."']

['Dedication to ""The universal Gallant""', '""My Lord, the unhappy fate which these scenes have met with, may, to some, make my presumption in offering them to your protection, appear extravagant; but distress puts on a different face in your grace\\\'s eye, with whom I know it will plead in their favour, that though they do not merit so great a patron, they at least want him."']
b: ['To his grace Charles duke of Marlborough.']

x: ['Advertisement to ""The universal gallant""', '""The cruel usage this poor play hath met with, may justify surprise the author, who in his whole life never did an inquiry to any one person living."']
['Prologue to ""The universal gallant""', 'Prologue is written in verse.', '""Bold is th\\\' attempt, in this nice-judging age,--- To try at fame, by pleasing the stage."']
['Epilogue is written in verse.', 'Epilogue to ""The universal gallant""', '""The play being done, according to our laws,--- I come to plead with you our author\\\'s cause."']

['Epilogue is written in verse.', 'Epilogue to ""Pasquin""', '""The play once done, the epilogue, by rule,--- Should come and turn it all to ridicule;--- Should tell the ladies that the tragic-bards,--- Who prate of virtue and her vast rewards,--- Are all in jest, and only fools shou\\\'d heed \\\'em;--- For all wife women flock to Mother Nedham."']

['Preface to the dedication of ""The historical register""', '""As no man hath a more stern and inflexible hatred to flattery than myself, it hath been usual with me to send most of my performances into the world without the ornament of those epistolary prefaces, commonly called dedications; a custom however highly censured by my bookseller, who affirms it a most unchristian practice: a patron is, says he, a kind of godfather to a book, and a good author ought as carefully to provide a patron to his works, as a good parent should a godfather to his children: he carries this very far, and draws several resemblances between those two offices (for having in the course of his trade with dramatick writers, purchased, at a moderate computation, the see-simple of one hundred thousand similies, he is perhaps the most expert in their application, and most capable of shewing likeness, in things utterly unlike, of any man living)."']

['Dedication to ""The historical register""', '""I hope you will pardon the presumption of this dedication, since I really did not know in what manner to apply for your lave; and since I expect no present in return: (the reason I conceive. which first introduc\\\'d the ceremony of asking leave among dedicators:) for surely it is somewhat absurd to ask a man leave to flatte rhim; and he must be a very impudent or simple fellow, or both, who will give it."']

['Dedication to ""Tumble-down Dick""', '""Sir, though Pasquin has put dedications in so ridiculous a light, that patrons may, perhaps, pay some shame for the future for reading their own praises; yet, I hope you will not begin to be affected with so torublesome a passion, when I tell you, I know no man in England to whom I can so properly dedicate the following pages as yourself."']
b: ["To Mr. John Lun, vulgarly call\\'d esquire."]

x: ['Note in ""Tumble-down Dick""', '""Phaeton was the son of Phoebus, and Clymene a Grecian oysterwench"']

['Prologue is written in verse.', 'Prologue to ""The wedding-day""', '""Gentlemen and ladies, we must beg your indulgence, and humbly hope you\\\'ll not be offended--- At an accident that has happen\\\'d to-night, which was not in the least intended,--- I assure you: if you please, your money shall be return\\\'d."']
['Epilogue is written in verse.', 'Epilogue to ""The wedding-day""', '""The trial ended, and the sentence o\\\'er,--- The criminal stands mute, and pleads no more."']
b: ['Epilogue. Written by a friend, and spoken by Mrs. Woffington.']

['Dedication to ""The fathers""', '""My lord, the author of this play was an upright, useful, and distinguished magistrate for the county of Middlesex; and by his publications laid the foundation of many wholesome laws for the support of good order and subordination in this metropolis, the effects of which have been, and now are, forcibly felt by the public."']
b: ['To his grace the Duke of Northumberland, lord lieutenant of the county of Middlesex, and master of the horse to the king.']

x: ['Epilogue in verse.', 'Epilogue to ""The fathers""', '""Prologues and epilogues-- to speak the phrase--- Which suits the warlike spirit if these days--- Are cannon charg\\\'d, or sho\\\'d be charg\\\'d, with wit,--- Which, pointed well, each rising folly hit;--- By a late gen\\\'ral who commanded here,--- And fought our bloodless battles many a year!"']
b: ['Epilogue. Written by Mr. Garrick, and spoken by Miss Young.']

x: ['Table of contents to ""Journey from this world to the next""']

['Introduction to ""Journey from this world to the next""', '""Whether the ensuing pages were really the dream or vision of some very pious and holy person; or whether they were really written in the other world, and sent back to this, which is the opinion of many (though I think too much inclining to superstition); or lately, whether, as infinitely the greatest part imagine, they were really the production of some choice inhabitant of New Bethlehem, is not necessary nor easy to determine."']
['Table of contents to ""The history of the adventures of Joseph Andrews, and his friend Mr. Abraham Adams.""']
['Footnotes on p.11, 25, 32, 33, 88, 124, 236, 288, 353', 'Marked with various symbols.']

['Preface to ""The history of the adventures of Joseph Andrews, and his friend Mr. Abraham Adams.""', '""As it is possible the mere English reader may have a different idea of romance from the author of these little volumes; and may consequently expect a kind of entertainment not to be found, nor which was even intended, in the following pages; it may not be improper to premise a few words concerning this kind of writing, which I do not remember to have seen hitherto attempted in our language."']

['Preface of ""David Simple"" at the end of ""The adventures of Joseph Andrews""', '""As so many worthy persons have, I am told, ascribed the honour of this performance to me, they will not be surprized at seeing my name to this preface; nor am I very insincere, when I call it an honour, for if the authors of the age are amongst the number of these, who conferred it on me, I know very few of them to whom I shall return the compliment of such a suspicion."']

['Preface of ""The familiar letters between the principal characters in David Simple""', '""The taste of the public, with regard to epistolary writing, having been much vitiated by some modern authors, it may not be amiss to premise some short matter concerning it in this place, that the reader may not expect another kind of entertainment than he will meet with in the following papers, nor impute the author\\\'s designed deviation from the common road, to any mistake or error."']
b: ['The preface to the familiar letters between the principal character in David Simple, and some others.']

x: ['Footnotes on p. 3, 17, 40, 159, 171, 188, 204, 380, 481', 'Marked by various symbols']

['Paratext is an except from main body text of ""Philosophical transactions""', '""Sir, some time since died here of old age, one Petrus Gualterus, a man well known in the learned world, and famous for nothing so much as for an extraordinary collection which he had made of the Chrysipi, an animal or vegetable; of which I doubt not but there are still some to be found in England: however, if that should be difficult, it may be easy to send some over to you; as they are at present very plentiful in these parts."']
b: ['Abstract of part of a letter from the Heer Rottenscrach in Germany, communicating observations in the Chyspius.']

x: ['Footnotes on p.6, 8, 9, 10, 13', 'Marked by various symbols']

['""Several papers relating to the terrestrial chrysipus, golden foot, or guinea, an inspect, or vegetable, which has this surprising property, that being cut into several pieces, each piece lives, and in a short time becomes as perfect an insect, or vegetable, as that of which it was originally only a part."']

['Reads: "Sir, Your defcent from the moft illuftrious Princes of Great Britain and Germany, and the high dignitiy of your title, which is truly paftoral, will, it is humbly hoped, in fome meafure justify the propriety, and apologize for the prefumption of dedicating This Discourse on the Origin and Use of Pastoral Poetry, and this Translation of Daphnis from the German into the English Language, to your Royal Highnefs. Pleafe to receive, Sir, from the tender hands of orphan innocence, this little wreath of flowers, with which the Mufes here prefent you; and may poetry, with the other polite arts, prove fome of the agreeable entertainments and fofter amufements of your younger years. The celebrated Mr. Gessner has truly and juftly obferved, that poetry has always been in the retinue of religion, and has greatly promoted her facred caufe; that it is a avery powerful and delightful method of teaching the leffons of morality; that it improves and refines the underftanding, and excites mankind to every laudable, worthy, and noble action. Small, therefore, as this poetical volume may appear to be, yet as it is of a moral tendency, there is fome pleafing encouragement to hope that it may not be altogether unacceptable to your Royal Highnefs. Formed by the wife precepts and illuftrious examples of your Royal Parents, that you may long inherit all their virtues, and fhare their glorious renown, fhall be the daily prayer of, Sir, Your Royal Highnefs\\\'s moft obedient, and moft humble Servant, Charlotte Butler."']

Let me befeech you to come to us in the country; you will there behold the fpring and me. If you will not, I fhall be quite angry with you; I am out of temper with you already. Mrs. N. tells me you have wrote a paftoral novel, which you call Daphnis, and I (fuch is your referve) muft know nothing of it. I lately fung it in the meadow by moon-fhine, and was quite charmed with it. On a fudden the nightingale began her melodious notes, and I was obliged to be filent, dearly as I love to hear myfelt fing. Fail not of being here next Thurfday; I will expect you in the evening; but bring Daphnis with you, or I fhall not any longer remain, Your Friend."']

['Explains that the book is intended to teach morality to children.', '"...he wishes to be useful to the rising generation.."', '"...we have not so largely borrowed from foreign writers, yet we have endeavoured to supply that deficiency by the introduction of original matter."', 'Describes the author\\\'s experience as the editor of Looking-glass for the Mind, how that work was loosely translated, and his purpose for producing/writing this mostly "original" work.', 'Speaks in the plural with "we".']
['Titles of 23 Chapters']

['"It is a maxim, with some critics, that Poetry is not to be translated. I am afraid, also, however loth we translators may be to subscribe to it, that there is more truth in this assertion than will be readily acknowleged. This is indubitably certain, that the most arduous task of a tranflator is to convey that happy combination of stile and sentiment, in which poesy consists, from one language to another."', 'Written primarily in the first-person-plural, with some first person as well', "Translator writes about the difficulties of translating foreign poetry and praises Mr. Gessner\\'s work."]

["Translator\\'s Preface", 'Note (ix) suggests that French poetry, because of its similarities to prose, is easier for a foreigner to read in its original, than is the foreign language poetry of other nations.  The translator goes on to suggest, in the text to which the note is appended, that this inaccessibility of foreign language poetry renders a translation such as his useful, even if it has to straddle a line between fidelity to the author and accessibility to the English reader.']

["Translator\\'s Preface", 'Note (xii) mentions that French to English translations may be overdone, and laments that too often, works are doubly translated, from the original language into French, and again from the French into English.  He claims the direct derivation of his own text from the German as a virtue that enables concision in his translation.']

['"The following poems are the produce of some of the most delightful moments of my life."', '"I sometimes leave the town in disgust; and seek relief in the charms of rural solitude."', '"Pastoral poetry ever makes choice of these rural scenes; it peoples them with inhabitants worthy so delightful an abode; it describes, after Nature, the life of these happy people, the simplicity of their manners, their customs and inclinations, in every state of good or ill fortune.', 'admires the natural, pastoral "poetry of the patriarchs" such as Homer, Theocritus', '"I know not whether it be out of compliance to our own manners, and with a view to acquire more general approbation, that they have departed so far from the example of Theocritus"']
['Lists the titles of 24 chapters', 'Note addressing the final 2 chapters. Mentions that they are somewhat different from the other chapters in that they are Arcadian Pastorals']

['The dedication reads: Gentlemen, That the hasty production of two short months, the greater part of which has been engaged in the humble pursuits of my avocation, should afford leisure to the author to produce a work, in all points so correspondently just as to meet that encouragement it otherwise might have done, the candid judicious reader will allow could scarcely be expected; the idea that gave rise to the opinions thus humbly brought into notice, are the consequence of some little observation, and much feeling resulting purely from the interest I have in the prosperity of the state, and the happiness and independence of the commercial world, forming, as it does, so very efficient a part of it; if the original idea is rather slightly pursued, and extraneous matter introduced, in order to render it somewhat more agreeable to the younger part of my readers, and to make it, at the same time, interesting to the lovely and amiable part of the other sex, I trust the desire of so doing will excuse the deviation, it being intended only faintly to pourtray to the intelligent reader what has eventually carried misery into many truly respectable families."']
b: ['Dedicated with all due deference and respect, to that very respectable body of men, the merchants and traders of the British Empire']

['Opens with, "This small volume of tales or stories is collected for thy diversion and instruction, and may serve to shew thee what subtle devices and malicious accusations were formerly used to attain grandeur, and gratifie malicious and ambitious persons."', 'Addressed entirely in second person.']

['"Madam, Though the practice of dedicating books to distinguished characters has, like other things, been perverted in some instances to low purposes, yet in its origin it was neither unnatural nor unuseful [...] The author was animated with the idea that at least one good judge, whom he was ambitious to please, would read what he wrote: and, in writing, the same idea operated as a monitor, that no sentiment or expression should be suffered to escape the pen of the author, that the judgement, the taste, or the virtue of the party addressed might be ready to condemn. It is on these principles that I have presumed to address to your Grace The Labyrinths of Life, intended to shew, that amidst all the fluctuations of human affairs, however surprising, there is, sooner or latter, a reward for patient and preserving probity and honour."']
b: ['To her grace, the Duchess of Leeds']

b: ["To Mrs. Eliza Haywood, on her novel call\\'d Love in excess, &c."]

x: ['"The writer of the following sheets was prevailed upon to make them public, by the Lady to whom they are addressed, who thought the conduct of Eliza, in some of the most trying circumstances of life, would afford a useful lesson for her sex, and whose amiable character deserved to be drawn from obscurity. Those who read only for amusement, will find themselves disappointed; if, in this little performance, they expect to meet with any of those surprising turns of fortune, so easily created by the imagination, but which the judgement can never realize. The History of Eliza is a narrative of facts, which gives the relator no claim to the merit of invention; if the public is pleased with her manner of relating them, her expectations will be more than answered."']

March 11, 1781.', 'First line reads: Madam, Chance put into my hand an old worn-out pen of Yorick\\\'s; ----- I gazed on it with the enthusiasm that took possession of your Ladyship\\\'s bosom, when his recording angel entranc\\\'d your attention! ----- "This pen," whispered my genius, "may do wonders yet; ----- whip out your knife, ----- put it in repair; ----- if this world presents a blank of ingenuity, take a trip to that of invention! you are certain of the prize of fame, while you brandish this renowned talisman!"']

['First lines read: "When I sat down to collect the particulars of the following work, the uncommon success of which stimulates me to a continuation, which will be ready for my numerous readers in a short time, I examined every character introduced with the equitable eye of justice. When I exhibited them to the inspection of those powerful members of society, genius and friendship, I was led to think the colouring beautiful, and the execution every way characteristically just."', 'Addresses criticism of "my strictures on Mr. Garrick", to which he replies: "If those elevated admirerers of Mr. G. who will not think of him any other than the paragon of perfection, while his great powers ennobled the dramatic muse, will take the trouble of scrutinizing his conduct, as manager and dramatic reviewer, and leave husband, brother, friend, out of the question, they will not think me divested of feeling, nor brand me as the disturber of his renowned manes. Mr. Garrick\\\'s dramatic fame I bow down to with as much reverence, as the warmest idolater at his shrine; but detest, with the majority of mankind, his parsimonious principles [...]"']

In an age where the harvest of literature is all got in, and such a number of leasers croud over the field as at present exist, it is next to a miracle to pick up any thing worthy attention. ----- Some gentlemen reviewers wantonly cut a hole in my sack it is true; and endeavoured to rob me of property; but what could I expect, when I had the partisans of a host of foes to combat with?"', 'Continues to comment on reviewers, thanking "the gentleman that conducts the London Magazine" for being "above looking for a bribe from any of the injured parties," and concluding with an adress to reviewers: "[...] no, gentlemen, you may endeavour, but by the invincible spirit of genius, you shall never rob me of my pen ----- nor break my heart."']

['First lines read: "The eastern way of writing hath been justly admired in all ages.  The bold metaphors and noble simplicity almost peculiar to the orientals add a lustre to their compositions, not to be rivalled by the greatest orators of Greece and Rome."', 'Comments on translations from Arabic: " [...] even the English reader may form some idea of their sublime writings, by the translation of the scriptures, which yet falls infinitely short of the divine original. The blooming flowers of the east lose a great deal of their fragrancy and liveliness of color, become more languid and sickly, by being transplanted to the colder climates of the North [...] I have, in the following pages, endeavoured to shadow out some of the beauties of the original Arabic; and if I have failed in the copy, I hope the candid reader will pardon me, since the picture is almost inimitable, at least a very difficult task for an unexperienced hand."']

['Description: "Poetical Society at B---H E----N.----Ancient poetrical recitals.-----Poets vindicated from a culpable adulation."', 'The author discusses what some critics might say about his new work such as, "Again! what, more last words? why this man is \\\'Partbis mendacior;\\\' a greater lyar than any party newswriter." The author writes, "Such probably will be the remark of some morose critic; if any such has vouchsafed to pay any degree of attention to a hint or two in the first volume of this triffling work. Now, tho\\\' the author cannot plead the importunity of his friends, or the importunity of his creditors (the honester plea perhaps of many a modern poet) for publishing his amusements; he can plead the earnest solicitation of the former, for writing a greater part of them. The musical drama, in particular, is a species of composition, in which he was so far from having any idea of engaging, that when he was requested, by a young man of a noble family, to whom he had great obligations, to write something of that kind for a particular purpose, he would have evaded his friend\\\'s request, by observing, that he might as well employ a country carpenter to make a harpsicord or an organ, as the author in a branch of business with which he was totally unacquainted. As unexpected incident having prevented its being made use of as intended, the author can only judge of its merit through the fallacious medium of partial friendship."', 'As regards the origin of this work, the author explains: "As for those miscellaneous pieces which make a considerable part of this volume, they were written at the earnest solicitation of an obliging and respectable neighbor who instituted, and has with so much eclat conducted, the poetical society at B---E----N."']

['First lines read: "There are people in the world who think their lives well employed in collecting shells; there are others not less satisfied to spend theirs in classing butterflies. ['Written in the first person, the introduction is signed by Ophelia, and addresses "Your Ladyship," who evidently compelled the fictional character to write her account: "Your Ladyship had little compassion either on yourself or me, when you desired me to write you an exact account of every circumstance of my life, and even of my thoughts, or you did not consider the long detail into which this lead me [...] You expressly desire to know the impressions I recieved from the first view of customs so unlike what I had ever seen, at a time when they are become so familiar to me, that I almost forgot many of them were ever otherwise."']

type: A novel describing Philadelphia during the yellow fever epidemic in 1793.

x: ['Signed, "C. B. B."', '"The evils of pestilence by which this city has lately been afflicted will probably form an aera in its history.  The schemes of reformation and improvement to which they will give birth, or, if no efforts of human wisdom can avail to avert the periodical visitations of this calamity, the change in manners and population which they will produce, will be, in the highest degree, memorable. [...]"']

['First lines read: "In sending into the world a work so unlike those of my former writings, which have been honored by its approbation, I feel some degree of that apprehension which an author is sensible of on a first draft of publication. This arises partly from my doubts of succeeding so well in letters as in narrative; and partly from a supposition, that there are readers, to whom the fictitious occurences, and others to whom the political remarks in these volumes may be displeasing."', 'Goes on to offer excuses both for the quality of the novel ("I apologize for the typographical errors of the work, which may have been in some measure occasioned by the detached and hurried way, in which the sheets were sometimes sent to the press when I was at a distance from it [...]") and the political opinions expressed within it ("the political passages dispersed through the work [...] are for the most part, drawn from conversations to which I have been a witness, in England and France, during the last twelve months. In carrying on my story in those countries, and at a period when their political situation [...] is the general topic of discourse in both; I have given my imaginary characters the arguments I have heard on both sides [...]").', 'Additionally discusses the role of women in thinking about politics.', 'Dated "London, June 20, 1792."']

['First lines read: "The following narrative is intended to answer a purpose more general and important than immediately appears on the face of it. While one party pleads for reformation and change, the other extols in the warmest terms the existing constitution of society."', 'Addresses the purpose of the book: "It is now known to philosophers that the spirit and character of the government intrudes itself into every rank of society. But this is a truth highly worthy to be communicated to persons whom books of science and philosophy are never likely to reach."', 'On page vi, the first section ends and is dated May 12, 1794. Following, it goes on: "This preface was withdrawn in the original edition, in compliance with the alarms of booksellers [...] Terror was the order of the day; and it was feared that even the humble novelist might be shown to be constructively a traitor." ['First sentences read: "All is over. b: ['Epistle dedicatory to the year two thousand five hundred.']

['The preface begins, "As soon as my good fortune had thrown the following curious dialogues into my hands, I determined forthwith to give them in full measure, and in the best manner, to the deserving public.  With this view, having enriched them with a course of notes critical and explanatory, I sent them to a bookseller of good credit [...]"', 'The editor includes an excerpt of his conversation with the bookseller to whom he sent the dialogues for publication.  The editor thinks his dialogues highly saleable, and requests 2,000 copies; the bookseller, raising objections to the posthumous nature of the works and their not being novels, among other difficulties, refuses to print above 500.  The entire exchange is formatted as a dramatic dialogue between the editor and the bookseller.  The editor concludes as follows: "But for the dialogues themselves, let me hear no more of your objections.  Not but I believe they are as good as anybody else will ever bring against them.  And for that reason I will even set them down and make a preface of them, that ill-disposed men may see how little the editor apprehends from the worst that can be said against them."']

['Begins: "While these sheets were in the press, and when the greater part of them had been printed off, the new history of England under the house of Tudor came forth, and chanced to fall into the hands of the editor.  It was amusing to him to observe, in this work, a design carried on, with no small art, to advance that very system of policy which the concluding dialogues in this collection seemed effectually to have overthrown."']

b: ['To the right honourable the Earl of Middlesex. Master of the Horse to his Royal Highness the Prince of Wales.']

x: ['The preface is mostly about the original author and the problems of translation.', 'Begins with, "The author of the following sheets is well known in all the polite parts of Europe, by means of a variety of writings he has publish\\\'d; and which gained him so much applause, in his native country, that he was judg\\\'d worthy of a seat in that assembly, whence some of the noblest literary productions have issued."']

['Appears to have been printed with the 1634 edition "The longtime interval between the first three editions and this of 1634 [...]"', 'First lines read: "Although our information respecting the domestic habits of our ancestors is but scanty, it seems agreed upon, that, in the infancy, or rather the absence of literature and literary taste, romances were very generally read, and served to fill up the hours that are now devoted either to study, or to more refined amusements. Such, indeed, was the demand for these extravagant fictions, that our earliest printers employed their skill on them, and gave them a much wider circulation than when confined to manuscripts, and in the hands of the wealthy only."', 'Goes on to give a history of the publication of the work. It was "first printed by Caxton, in 1485"; the second edition "was printed by Wynken de Worde in 1498"; and a third edition "was printed by Thomas East, but without date." Additionally gives information on where surviving copies of these editions were held.']

x: ['Describes how the book came about: after presenting Edward the Fourth with a book on Godfrey, Edward requested the author to "imprint the history of the said noble king and conqueror, king Arthur." The author replied "that divers men hold opinios that there was no such Arthur, and that all books as be made of him be feigned matters and fables." The remainder of the preface points to literary and archaelogical evidence that king Arthur existed, including earlier editions of the text in various languages.']

The fourth and final book demonstrates how the hero "does not et a bit nearer his mistress, than where we just now left him," and is divided into chapters I-XVI.']

[...]"', 'Preface goes on to discuss the politics of translation, such as "whether it ever be allowable in a translator to vary from his original" (xvi), as well as the relative ability of translators of various nationalities, such as the French ("seldom fortunate in translating from any language" (xxiii)) and the Italians ("who have a better translation of Milton than we can boast, of any book whatever" (xxiv)). ['First line reads: "It being customary for every scribbler, when they transmit their works to the public, to give some account of the subject they treat of, and the motives that induced them to such an undertaking, (by way of preface) I therefore beg leave to acquaint the perusers of the following sheets, that they are the production of a female pen [...]"', 'Goes on to describe the content of the book, which "have indeed nothing to recommend them to the readers attention, (except being founded on facts) [...]".']

['Begins with a character sketch of the Chevalier de Mainvillers, who "was the delight of the gay, the young and the fair" and "had the advantage of a double experience [...] in the double capacity of a man of letters, and the fine gentleman." The author of the preface notes that "his faults and vices are very numerous" and advises "none therefore [...] pretend to imitate him in his guilty pleasures." The editor then addresses the reader, apologizing for "frequently fail[ing] in translating the sallies of our author\\\'s wit" and giving an account of the difficulties of translation. A description of the success of the French edition, and excerpts from a review published in The Novelle Litteraires of France, are also included.']

['The table of contents divides the text into Book I (containing chapters I-XIV) and Book II (chapters I-XVIII).  Each chapter listing is accompanied by a brief description and a page number.', 'History of Pompey']
["The table of contents lists all of Zilia\\'s letters and includes brief descriptions of each such as the addressee and general intent.", 'Letters written by a Peruvian Princess']

['Begins: "If truth, when it strays from probability, usually loses its credit in the eye of reason, it is for a short time only; but, let it contradict prejudice ever so little, and seldom shall it find grace before that tribunal. What then ought not the editor of this work to fear, in presenting to the public the letters of a young Peruvian, whose stile and thoughts so little agree with the mean idea which an unjust prejudice has caused us to form of her nation? Enriched by the precious spoils of Peru, we ought, at least, to regard the inhabitants of that part of the world as a magnificent people; and the sentiment of respect is not very remote from the idea of magnificence. But so prejudiced are we always in our own favour, that we rate the merit of other nations not only in proportion as their manners imitate ours, but in proportion as their tongues approach nearer to our Idiom. How can one be a Persian? We despite the Indians, and hardly grant a thinking soul to those unhappy people: yet their history is in every one\\\'s hands, and abounds with monuments of the sagacity of their minds, and the solidity of their philosophy. The apologist of humanity and of beautiful nature has traced the out-lines of the Indian manners in a dramatic poem, the subject of which divides the glory with the execution.With so much light given us into the characters of these people, there should seem no room to fear that original letters which only exhibit what we already know of the lively and natural wit of the Indians, are in danger of passing for a fiction. But, that prejudice any eyes? There is no fecundity against its judgement, and we should have been careful not to submit this work to it, if its empire has been without bounds. It seems needless to give notice, that the first letters of Zilia were translated by herself: every one must easily judge, that, being composed in a language, and traced in a manner equally unknown to us, this collection could never have reached us, if the same hand had not writ them in our tongue. We owe this translation to Zilia\\\'s leisure in her retreat: her complaisance in communicating them to the chevalier Deterville, and the permission he at last obtained to keep them, were the means that conveyed them into our hands."']

['In reference to the question "How can one be a Persian?"', 'Reads: "The translator apprehends this sentence to be a satirical repetition after some other French author. There were a few strokes marked in the same manner in one or two of the letters, which he did not take notice of, as he supposed they would be inintellible to the Engglish reader.']

['The translator explains his or her opinion on the French editor\\\'s use of the term "Oriental" in the "Advertisement of the French editor." It reads, "The French editor here uses Oriental for lofty and swelling, though the Peruvians, with respect to us, are certainly an Occidental people."', 'Letters written by a Peruvian Princess', 'Advertisement of the French Editor']

['Reads: "When I gave the first Part of the Peruvian Letters to the Publick, I did not dare to flatter myself that they would meet with so favourable an Acceptance as they have been honoured with. The Defects of Stile, the ingenuous simplicity, and the tender Sentiments which animated Zilia, and alone dictated all that she wrote the first Year of her Misfortunes; all appeared to me of a Character too opposite to the Prejudices of our Nation, for me to think it would amuse the French. Reasons so plausible would have diverted me from this Enterprize, if I had entertained the same Fears with Regard to the Sequel which I now publish, but which was of Necessity preceded by that, which appeared to found the Taste of the Publick. The Reader, however, will see with a single Glance, how much Preference is due to this Sequel. In the first Part of these Letters Zilia had not yet changed any thing but her Dress; But he will find in this a greater Progress than he could have expected from an Indian Capacity. The Princess Royal of Cusco looks no longer for the Peruvian Virgin behind the Glass, and her Reason\\\'s too much enlightened to refuse her Arm to a Physician. Her stile is corrected with as much Care as she was capable of bestowing on it, and her civilized Pen knows how to throw a Lustre upon whatever her Imagination furnishes. This is the Author\\\'s own Opinion, in a Letter which he wrote, and in which he discovers a tender Predelection for this Sequel."', 'Sequel of the Letters written by a Peruvian Princess']

['Begins: "It is a pretty general curiousity before one enters on the reading a book, to be inquisitive about who is its author, and with what intent it was written [...]". The author of the preface claims that this book "was written for the service of a daughter", and that the "vice" which appears in the title character is "to the rational mind the most striking of all lessons of morality," and therefore "permitted."']

['Work is divided into four books. "Adventures at Bath" contains chapters i-iv; "Her history after her arrival in London" contains chapters i-x; "Adventures at Paris" contains chapters i-vii; and "Adventures in a second journey to Paris" contains chapters i-ix.', 'Chapters are given a brief description and listed next to page numbers.']

['First lines read: "The ingenious gentlemen which composed the societies under the names of the Athenian Oracle, and of the British Apollo, having met with uncommon success in their answers to the several questions proposed. The compiler of this volume, so far as it relates to those gentlemen, thinking a collection of questions and answers of the comic kind, and chiefly relative to the sexes, would be no unpleasing entertainment; has, from a garden so plentifully stocked, gathered, as he imagines, the choicest fruits, and presents them here to the public."']
['A footnote which provides an explanatory definition to a word in a selection of verse appears on p. 200, in "The adventures of Sophia."']

['Transcription of the opening lines: "Besides the prefaces already affix\\\'d to each single volume of these letters, which contain particular answers to the objections and cavills of some, with solutions of the scruples and doubts made by others; as likewise critical explanations of passages, seeming obscure to all, in the English tranaslation of our spy: it is thought necessary to prefix something more by way of a general prefce, not so much regarding the translation as the seeming original abruptness and obscurity of our Arabian author himself in some places, with his frequent change of subjects, his digressions and startings from matter of fact, the then present wards, transactions, and intrigues of Christian courts, states, and kingdoms (for which he was chiefly sent to Paris) and his immethodical falling upon philosophical, divine, and moral contemplations, and even to ancient, obsolete histories, which some think were altogether foreign to his business."']
